Award.AwardTitle: Increasing the Participation of First-generation and Underrepresented Students in the Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supporting cohorts of upper division undergraduates at Eastern Washington University (EWU) who demonstrate academic potential, motivation for STEM, and financial need. Guiding objectives are: 1) to improve educational opportunities in the STEM disciplines by annually awarding scholarships to nine students; 2) to increase degree achievement by providing increased faculty mentoring and access to specialized student support services; 3) to build capacity in institutional practices that increase the retention of STEM students and of first generation and/or underrepresented minority students; and 4) to create and maintain community partnerships that increase EWU's visibility and generate training and employment opportunities for the students.

Notable project implementation components include mentoring, financial support, and enrichment activities designed to increase academic integration, motivation, identification with STEM, and retention to graduation. Students are recruited from three majors: Biology, Biochemistry, and Environmental Science which allows for: (1) an exploration of the interdisciplinary nature of STEM on the part of the cohort of scholarship recipients and (2) better matching of regional workforce needs with agency/industry partners. Encouragement of diversity in the STEM workforce is promoted through a combined incentive and support program to help recruit students, many of whom are first-generation college attendees and/or members of underrepresented groups in STEM. Finally, the project offers multiple mentoring experiences through cohort-building enrichment activities that include professional development, career planning, information literacy and civic engagement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM program at Eastern Washington University was funded by the Scholarships in STEM program of the National Science Foundation. The program combined scholarship support with the development of monthly activities related to professional development, community engagement, career services, information literacy, and faculty mentoring. Creating and refining these activities required collaboration between STEM faculty, non-STEM faculty, university staff and administrators, community (nonprofit) partners and regional STEM employer partners. Through surveys administered to our scholars, we learned that we were successful at creating meaningful experiences for our multidisciplinary cohorts of scholars and that faculty language about activities influenced scholar attitudes about the activities.

 

From 2014 – 2019, the program supported 49 undergraduate students during their junior and/or senior years with annual $7,000 scholarships. The S-STEM scholars were declared majors in Biology, Chemistry/Biochemistry, or Environmental Science. We exceeded our goals related to supporting students who are from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines; 79% of the scholars are female, first-generation college students and/or from underrepresented racial or ethnic minority groups. All of the scholars graduated or are on track to graduate on time. More than a third of the scholars continued into graduate programs and nearly half were employed in a STEM discipline within one year of graduation. Several of the scholars were hired into internships or full-time positions by our employer partners. The scholarship support enabled the scholars to decrease the number of hours of paid employment per week and focus on activities related to their education. Most of those scholars who continued to work were able to shift to STEM-related or on-campus employment such as tutoring or research experience, which tends to pay less but is more beneficial for their career preparation. We did not find that students improved their grade point average once on scholarship support; instead, they increased their participation in co-curricular activities on campus that were separate from the S-STEM monthly activities. These results suggest that the scholars recognized that the (newly) free time in their schedules that resulted from decreasing their work commitments was best used in building the skills and experiences that STEM employers find desirable.


Last Modified: 05/29/2020
Modified by: Joanna Joyner-Matos

Creating and refining these activities required collaboration between STEM faculty, non-STEM faculty, university staff and administrators, community (nonprofit) partners and regional STEM employer partners. Through surveys administered to our scholars, we learned that we were successful at creating meaningful experiences for our multidisciplinary cohorts of scholars and that faculty language about activities influenced scholar attitudes about the activities. From 2014 – 2019, the program supported 49 undergraduate students during their junior and/or senior years with annual $7,000 scholarships. The S-STEM scholars were declared majors in Biology, Chemistry/Biochemistry, or Environmental Science. We exceeded our goals related to supporting students who are from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines; 79% of the scholars are female, first-generation college students and/or from underrepresented racial or ethnic minority groups. All of the scholars graduated or are on track to graduate on time. More than a third of the scholars continued into graduate programs and nearly half were employed in a STEM discipline within one year of graduation. These results suggest that the scholars recognized that the (newly) free time in their schedules that resulted from decreasing their work commitments was best used in building the skills and experiences that STEM employers find desirable.
